sentences: Belle Stewart, born Isobella McGregor, (18 July 1906 – 4 September 1997) was a Scottish Traveller traditional singer.
Her biography, Queen Amang the Heather: the Life of Belle Stewart, was written by her daughter, Sheila Stewart, and published in 2006.
Early years ==
Sheila Stewart corrects the frequently cited birthdate of 17 July 1906 to the 18th.
Belle's father died when she was only 9 months old.
In the evenings they gathered at ceilidhs to exchange folk songs.
They married in secret on 17 August 1925 at Ballymoney in Northern Ireland.
Alec's father Jock Stewart (1869–1954) had been a champion violinist, supposedly the subject of the popular Scots and Irish drinking-song "Jock Stewart, A Man You Don't Meet Every Day".
Alec's father Jock Stewart (1869–1954) had been a champion violinist, supposedly the subject of the popular Scots and Irish drinking-song "Jock Stewart, A Man You Don't Meet Every Day".
Alec's mother, Nancy Campbell, reputedly had both a grandfather (Andy Campbell) and a grandmother sentenced to death by hanging in the 18th century for the crime of travelling.
A collection of her stories was published as The King o' the Black Art in 1987.
The following week Ewan MacColl visited the Stewart family.
A few months later the whole family received invitations to perform at MacColl's "Singers' Club" in London.
In March 1954 Hamish Henderson invited the Traveller family to do a concert in Edinburgh alongside "Auld Galoot" (Davie Stewart), Jeannie Robertson and Jimmy MacBeath.
Later in 1954 Douglas Kennedy and Peter Kennedy visited them and made recordings.
In the 1960s Alec Stewart made his living in the summer months by playing bagpipes to tourists in Glen Coe, Oban and Loch Ness.
In the 1960s Alec Stewart made his living in the summer months by playing bagpipes to tourists in Glen Coe, Oban and Loch Ness.
In 1965 the family recorded an album, The Stewarts of Blair.
"The Overgate", a folksong with some similarities to "Seventeen Come Sunday" has particular associations with the Robertson / Higgins / Stewart families of Travellers.
Belle recorded it in 1976.
In about 1970 the family spent a month performing in America.
In about 1970 the family spent a month performing in America.
Ewan MacColl and Peggy Seeger also compiled a collection of the folklore of Belle and other members of her family, called 'Till Doomsday in the Afternoon.
A BBC programme about the family was shown in 1980.
After the death of Alec they continued to tour, and appeared at a folk festival in Bologna in 1980 and at Lake Como in 1980, with Ian taking the place of chief piper.
After the death of Alec they continued to tour, and appeared at a folk festival in Bologna in 1980 and at Lake Como in 1980, with Ian taking the place of chief piper.
Stewart was awarded the British Empire Medal in 1981 for "an outstanding contribution to Scottish traditional music".
In 1986 she was honorary president of the Blairgowrie Folk Festival, where she also performed.
In the same year another television programme about her was broadcast.
In 1996 a series of three programmes about the family were broadcast on BBC Radio 2.
Another programme was made for Grampian Television in 1996.
Stewart died aged 91 in 1997.
